statement.p: Explain step by step how to find a singular value decomposition for an m \times n matrix A.
Give an example of a matrix 2 \times 2 whose eigenvalues are nonnegative but different from its singular values.

[MIT OCW] The question is about the matrix A=\mat{0 -1;4 0}
Find its eigenvalues and eigenvectors.
Solve the equation \dfrac{du}{dt} = Au starting witht the same vector u(0) at time t=0. In other words, solution u(t) is what combination of the eigenvectors of A?
Find the 3 matrices in the Singular Value Decomposition A=U\Sigma V^T in two steps. First, compute V and \Sigma using the matrix A^T A. Second, find the (orthonormal) columns of U.

ol.li: Since \det(A= \lambda I)=\lambda^2 + 4, the eigenvalues are 2i, -2i. Two associated eigenvectors are \vec{1 -2i}, \vec{1 2i}, though there are many other choices. u(0) is just the sum of these vectors.
One simply adds in the factors of e^{\lambda t} to each term, giving u(t)=e^{2it}\vec{1 -2i} + e^{-2it}\vec{1 2i}

statement.p: [MIT OCW] If A is a 3 \times 3 non-singular real matrix with singular values \sigma_1, \sigma_2, \sigma_3, then give the formulas in terms of \sigma_1, \sigma_2, \sigma_3 for \det(A^T A)= and |\det(A)|=.

answer.p: The eigenvalues of A^T A are the squares of the singular values of A, and the determinant is the product of the eigenvalues, so \det(A^T A)=\sigma_1^2 \sigma_2^2 \sigma_3^2. The singular value decomposition of A is A=U\Sigma V^T where U, V are orthogonal matrices and \Sigma is the diagonal matrix with diagonal entries \sigma_1, \sigma_2, \sigma_3. So \det(A) = \det(U)\det(\Sigma)\det(V^T). As \Sigma is diagonal we have \det(\Sigma)=\sigma_1\sigma_2\sigma_3. The determinant of an orthogonal matrix is \pm 1, so we see that |\det(A)|=\sigma_1\sigma_2\sigma_3.

statement.p: [MIT OCW] True or False: A singular matrix A cannot be similar to a non-singular matrix B.

answer.p: True. Similar matrices have the same eigenvalues, but B must have a zero eigenvalue and A must have nonzero eigenvalues.

statement.p:
[MIT OCW]
Suppose every row of A adds up to zero. Why is A singular?
Suppose every column of A adds up to zero. Why is A singular?

ol.li: In this case the sum of all the columns of A must be the zero column-vector, so A must be singular.
In this case the sum of all the rows of A must be the zero row-vector, so A must be singular.
